event: Born in Michigan.
Won first LEGO competition.
Published and circulated 'The Adventures of Creampuff,' a comic book series about my stuffed bunny.
Placed into a third-grade class while still in second grade.
My library issued a special card just for me because I checked out too many books.
Invented a new sport called Stitchball.
Placed 11th in the school spelling bee.
Won a Total War: Rome II video game strategy tournament.
The only student in 25 years to earn an A in my chemistry class.
Set the fastest smoothie-making time (21 seconds) ever recorded at any Tropical Smoothie location (over 1,500 stores).
Botched the intro to Swan Lake four times in a row at a piano recital.
Admitted to Columbia University.
Won Columbia’s first poker tournament.
Survived a fireworm sting.
Became a 3× intramural volleyball champion and 1× basketball champion.
Finalmente terminé la clase de español.
Benched 225 lbs.
Finally built this website I’ve been putting off.
Born in Pella, Macedonia, to King Philip II and Queen Olympias. Claimed descent from both Heracles and Achilles.
Tamed the untamable horse Bucephalus at age 12 by noticing it feared its own shadow. His father said, 'My boy, seek a kingdom equal to yourself—Macedonia is too small for you.'
Began tutoring under Aristotle at Mieza, where he studied ethics, medicine, rhetoric, and biology. Developed a lifelong love for Homer’s Iliad, which he kept under his pillow.
Appointed regent of Macedonia while Philip campaigned abroad. Suppressed a Thracian uprising and founded his first city, Alexandropolis.
Led a campaign in northern Greece, subduing rebellious tribes and establishing Macedonian garrisons.
Commanded the Companion Cavalry at the Battle of Chaeronea, crushing the elite Sacred Band of Thebes and securing Macedonian dominance over Greece.
Upon his father’s assassination, ascended to the throne. Executed rival claimants, rallied the army, and was proclaimed Hegemon of the Hellenic League.
Crushed revolts in the north and razed Thebes after its rebellion—spared only temples and Pindar’s house. Greek city-states submitted instantly.

Crossed the Hellespont into Asia Minor with ~40,000 troops, symbolically throwing a spear into Persian soil to claim Asia as his prize. Won the Battle of Granicus, freeing Greek cities under Persian rule.
